quoteFirst: The motion made at a previous meeting to invite Dr. Croke, Archbishop of Cashel, to lecture, in preference to having a street parade, was adopted by a vote of
quoteLast: , and the convention adjoined, subject to the call of officers. Most Rev. Dr. Croke sent a despatch saying it was impossible for him to accept the invitation.
title: Donahoe's Magazine, Volume 15, No. 3, March 1886
author: Various

quoteFirst: But in less than an hour--I can see the face of the clock now: it was
quoteLast: --I flung myself in my chair, panting for breath, and, as my mother said, as pale as if I had seen a ghost.  But I told her it was worse than that.
title: The Brick Moon, and Other Stories
author: Hale, Edward Everett, 1822-1909

quoteFirst: Some book-plate owners, not boastful of their titles, let us into their confidences as to their place of birth, age, and the like. The German book-plate, dated in 1618, of John Vennitzer, a knife-smith or cutler by trade, tells us that he was born at Nuremberg, at
quoteLast: in the afternoon on the 14th day of May, 1565. Vennitzer made money by his trade, and founded the Library of St.
title: Book-Plates
author: Hardy, William John, 1857-1919

quoteFirst: Charles Sumner of Massachusetts and Hon. J.B. Henderson of Missouri. Senator Trumbull of the Judiciary Committee, to whom the Senate resolutions were referred, reported a substitute for the amendment, which, in April, 1864, passed the Senate by a vote of
quoteLast: ; but reaching the House, June 15, it failed to get the necessary two-thirds vote and was defeated. At the next session of Congress the resolutions were again presented to the House, and after a protracted debate were passed (January 13, 1865) by a vote of one hundred and nineteen to fifty-six.
title:
The Every-day Life of Abraham Lincoln
A Narrative And Descriptive Biography With Pen-Pictures And Personal
Recollections By Those Who Knew Him
author: Browne, Francis F. (Francis Fisher), 1843-1913

quoteLast: --I flung myself in my chair, panting for breath, and, as my mother said, as pale as if I had seen a ghost. But I told her it was worse than that.
title: Crusoe in New York, and other tales

quoteLast: a flag of truce was hoisted at the citadel, and the firing ceased. An officer came off to apologize for the flag of truce being fired at by mistake, and to know what terms we would grant. Our answer was, that the garrison should surrender at discretion, and an hour given for deliberation; at the expiration of which time a peremptory refusal was returned, and the firing recommenced on both sides; the remainder of the troops were landed, and the heights occupied to the right and left of the town.
title: Memoir of the Life and Services of Vice-Admiral Sir Jahleel Brenton, Baronet, K.C.B.
author: Raikes, Henry, 1782-1854 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Unlike Saturn, retrogrades nearly one degree of arc during the present month, and shines from early eve to break of day, rising on the 1st at 5:18 p. m., and setting on the 2d at
quoteLast: ; on the 16th, rising at 4:17 p. m., and setting next morning at 4:21; and on the 30th, rising at 3:19 p. m., and setting May 1st at 3:23 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, April 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
